title: Can you use any SIM card in any phone? - Quora

response.answer_text: Generally No, but there is a easy chance to make it work. I’ll only focus on Physical SIM cards for this questions. Here are the restrictions Size - Mini, Micro or Nano. Now the good news is that basic circuit is the same so it’s just the size difference which is irrelevant on how it performs. So you can either cut it or install an in-expensive SIM jacket to adjust the size accordingly.Phone compatibility - Though your carrier may say that the phone is incompatible there is a chance it’ll still work unless it’s locked. New phones support lot of bands & there may be limitation in usage but for average consumer they won’t even notice the difference.Lock - Generally at time of activation, SIMs are activated on a specific SIM Card, but apart from that, there isn’t any issue. We at Most Secure and Private Cellphone Plan however have implemented an advanced protection that triggers a redflag if the SIM Card is removed from phone it was registered unless notified to us before hand.

No. Some phones takes only nano sim, some take micro sim and the rest take regular ones. Some phones do not support bands used in certain countries and can be used only in the country where they are sold. Some phones do not support bands used by few carriers. GSM phones do not support CDMA sim and vice versa; some phones accept both. Some phones are locked to the carrier from whom you purchased and cannot be used with a sim from another carrier.

These days - almost certainly. Previously, most handsets were sold ‘tied’ to a particular network. You could swap the SIM card IF it was on the same network (for example 3 Mobile) - but you could’t put (say) an O2 card in a 3 Mobile phone. You had to take it to a phone shop and pay a (extortionate) ‘fee’ for having the phone unlocked. These days it’s different. Mobiles (here in the UK at least) are sold ‘unlocked’ - in that they’ll accept any SIM that physically fits the slot in the handset.

Not sure what you mean exactly but if you were curious, for iPhones at least, you can use a SIM card for other phones and still keep the same plan, data plan and number. I’ve actually done this many times before on my phones. Not sure how it works with other phones but almost sure it works the same way.

I’m pretty sure, yes it should work. However there are a few things you need to know: If you were switching from iPhone to iPhone, as Michael Jones said, it should work. The SIM card sizes are the same. It only goes down to whether the phone you’re transferring the SIM card to is locked, on the same carrier as the SIM card, or if it’s unlocked. However, if you’re transferring it to another device apart from iPhone (i.e. Android (Samsung, Google, LG, Moto, etc.), Windows Phone), then you may have a bit of trouble. First you have to make sure the SIM sizes are the same. Then you can worry about whether: The second phone is locked on a specific carrier that is not the same carrier as the SIM card - Will not work The second phone is locked on a specific carrier that IS on the same carrier as the SIM card - will work The second phone is unlocked - generally will work. Again some phones may not follow these exact lines, and have different rules, but this is the general idea

My answer is from my experience. In the past certain sim cards were not interchangeable . Depending on your carrier, they would make them compatible with Verizon, AT&T, etc..phones. However now, some Sims are compatible with any phone, as mine is.

As long as the phone isn’t locked down to a specific other carrier, yes. (In the UK, whilst you’re under contract your phone is locked down to that carrier, eg O2. If you put a Vodaphone SIM in, it probably won’t work. The phone has to be unlocked by the carrier first.)
